WATER SUPPLY SECTOR OVERVIEW 1.1 Some 217 million people in India live in urban areas (1991 census) and nearly 60% of India's Net Domestic Product is generated in its towns and cities. Forecasts by the United Nations suggest that the urban population may grow by over 400 million up to the year 2025. Urban growth is placing great strain on already under-provided urban infrastructure and services, especially water supply. There is an urgent need for sustainable modes of delivery which must be compatible with, and meet the requirements of a market-oriented economy while providing efficient and effective safety nets of protection for the urban poor. A. Water Supply Sector Development and Organization 1.2 Service Levels in Urban India. In 1992 the proportion of the Indian urban population receiving water supply was 85% with approximately two-thirds served by private connections and one-third by standposts. Coverage figures alone are an inadequate indicator of the status of the water supply sector, however, and mask the issues of the level of service. In most Indian cities, supplies to the consumer are intermittent and are frequently reduced to as little as two hours a day, often at very low pressures. This has implications for the quality of water received by the consumer and increases the risk of health- threatening contamination as a result of back-flow in the poorly maintained distribution systems. Intermittent supplies to industrial consumers also have serious economic implications for production particularly in water-intensive industries, such as petro-chemicals, which invest heavily in their own sources, storage and pumping equipment. 1.3 Sector Organization at National and State Levels. Under India's constitution, the primary responsibility for water supply rests with the states. Central Government influences the sector through approvals of state development plans and through operations of central level institutions. The central focal point is the Ministry of Urban Affairs and Employment. Central Government provides technical reviews of major investment proposals from the states and guidance on design standards, coordination of training and support for funding institutions such as the Housing and Urban Development Corporation of India (HUDCO). 1.4 Within the framework set by Central Government, state governments determine the policies for the water supply sector and influence sector developments through the processes of regulation of sector agencies and resource allocations from state budgets. It is common for state governments in India to have established special purpose entities to provide the planning, design and construction of water supply and sanitation infrastructure. In Tamil Nadu this is with the Tamil Nadu Water Supply and Drainage Board (TWAD). Municipalities in India are the primary local bodies responsible for providing water supply in urban areas though for a few of the larger cities, including Madras, special purpose entities have been established. In Madras this is the Madras Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (MMWSSB, sometimes referred to as Madras MetroWater). 1.5 Tamil Nadu is located in the south of India and ranks seventh in state population and eleventh in area. Madras is the State's capital, and the nation's fourth largest metropolitan area. The population of
 the Madras Metropolitan Area (MMA) is 5.9 million (1991 census) which includes the Madras Metropolitan Corporation (MMC) with 3.8 million and surrounding jurisdictions covering six municipal areas, three municipal townships, 27 town panchayats, 10 panchayat unions and one contonment board which together, amount to 2.1 million. Madras is an administrative and commercial center and has a number of industries including the port, textiles, electrical equipment, machinery and vehicles with petro-chemical and fertilizer industries in north Madras. 1.6 Existing Sources and Distribution in Madras. Water supply for Madras is currently obtained from ground water sources, about 13 in number depending on how they are categorized into groups, and three inter-connected reservoirs at Poondi, Cholavaram and Redhills. A recent survey of consumers has found that many have their own supplies of groundwater obtained from shallow wells which, for the domestic sector, are used for washing and cleaning purposes leaving the piped supply for drinking and cooking. There has been underinvestment in the water distribution system for many years, leading to poor coverage, inequitable distribution and considerable wastage through leakage and abuse. 1.7 Existing Level of Service in Madras. The maximum availability of water for Madras from existing sources is about 290 mid which provides an average for areas covered of about 70 liters/capita/day (Ipcd) inclusive of demands by industry and other non-domestic consumers. The corresponding figures for other cities are Bombay 253, Delhi 220, Calcutta 190 and Bangalore 125 Ipcd, making Madras the lowest-supplied metropolitan area in India. The average per capita domestic daily availability in Madras is only 47 liters which is well below the Indian standard of 70-100 lpcd for individual connections in urban areas and 50 Ipcd for consumers using stand pipes. 1.8 In poor monsoon years, the water supply is reduced to periods of one to three hours on alternate days. Occasionally this low level of supply for domestic use can only be maintained by diversion of industrial water supply requiring industries to curtail or even cease their operations. Failure of the monsoon combined with the practice of overdrawing the reservoir system has in the past resulted in almost complete depletion of the storage reservoirs. 1.9 TWAD. With the exception of the MMA, the State-wide responsibility for planning, design and construction of water supply and sewerage systems rests with TWAD. This organization was established in 1971 for the purpose of regulating and developing drinking water and drainage investments. TWAD has no responsibility for irrigation which has rested with the irrigation wing of the State Government's Public Works Department (PWD), reorganized in early 1995 into the Water Resources Organization (WRO). Generally, after commissioning, TWAD hands projects over to local bodies for operation and maintenance (O&M). TWAD is the oldest board of this type in the country and has well developed policies and procedures. 1.10 MMWSSB. MMWSSB was formed as an autonomous body in 1978, and assumed sector responsibilities formerly held by MMC. Over time its jurisdiction has extended to the MMA. MMWSSB is a state agency, with the Chairman and Managing Director appointed by the State Government. The Secretary to Government for Municipal Administration and Water Supply and other senior secretaries are its directors. MMWSSB is organized in six separate sections for management purposes: water supply and sewerage construction; operations; resource planning, project planning and design; finance, accounting and internal audit; personnel and administration; and, inventory control and purchasing. The total current labor force is 3,950, which has fallen since 1978 from 6,878. MMWSSB is generally a well run utility and over the years has expanded its management systems to include performnance budgeting and cost centers. MMWSSB has also computerized its billing and collection, budgeting and planning. As at August 1994, there were 220,000 consumers of which 10, 000,
 -3 - predominantly industrial and commercial consumers, were metered. There are 7,554 stand pipes in the city serving 1.8 million people. B. Strategies of Governments 1.11 Central Government. A national water policy document produced by the GOI's Ministry of Water Resources in 1987 provided clear guidelines in the allocation of priorities, stating that drinking water would be top priority in the planning and operation of water systems. It stressed that with the increasing scarcity of water, "optimal, economical and equitable use has become a matter of the utmost urgency". Consistent with this approach, strategies identified in India's Eighth Five Year Plan (1992-97) include: (a) management of water as a commodity, as with any other resource; (b) the need to charge appropriate tariffs to cover O&M and development costs where appropriate; (c) encouragement of the private sector to develop water supply projects; (d) reduction of pollution by provision of appropriate treatment facilities for waste and sewage; and (e) separation of the water supply and sanitation budget from general municipal budgets for better planning, monitoring and control. Water resource management has become an emerging feature of Central Government's strategy since the start of the Eighth Plan. However, there is still a major gap between strategy and practice on the ground. 1.12 State Governments. While many States recognize the importance of adopting Central Government strategies for the sector, these still need to be addressed with appropriate policies and actions. Significant reform in the sector is taking place in only a few states, including Tamil Nadu. A State Water Policy paper was issued by GOTN in 1994 which is consistent with GOI's paper. Tamil Nadu was the first state to prepare such a paper. Major sector issues which need to be addressed in the context of the project are indicated below. C. Sector Issues 1.13 Water Resource Management. There is a need for coherent state water resource policies incorporating planning of river basins and covering all uses, as spelt out in the Bank's policy paper, Water Resources Management (1993) which was discussed by the Board in May, 1993. State agencies, including the irrigation departments, special agencies like TWAD and the municipalities need to have greater regard to improvements in financial, managerial and technical performance; more autonomy, and increased user involvement in management matters. A proposed Bank project, the Tamil Nadu Water Resources Consolidation Project, would support initiatives in the State to introduce multi-sectoral water plann;ng based on river basins, and to strengthen the State's institutional and technical capability in water development, management and planning. It would build on the Tamil Nadu Drinking Water Supply Sector Plan Study which has just been completed under the Tamil Nadu Water Supply and Sanitation Project (see para. 1.20). It is recognized that growing needs of urban centers are likely increasingly to dominate investment choices. The importance of these choices is reflected in the establishment of an apex "Water Resources Control and Review Council" as the State's most senior body, chaired by the Chief Minister and with three other key Ministers as Vice Chairmen. TWAD and MMWSSB are represented in the Council.
 - 4 - 1.14 Water Conservation. The demand for additional urban water supply infrastructure and services arises from the accommodation of growth and from existing deficiencies in either coverage or service levels, or both. In most urban areas there is an overriding need to increase the quantity of piped water to consumers in order to reduce intermittent supplies and low pressures. This requires additional sources and strengthened and enlarged distribution systems. Such improvements require a combination of superior organization to facilitate these changes, better mobilization of resources to pay for them, greater attention to the quality of construction, operation and maintenance of assets, and measures to conserve water including appropriate tariff structures and levels. The proposed project addresses these concerns and has a component which reflects these requirements for conservation of water including metering, leak detection and repair and progressive introduction of tariff reforms. 1.15 Cost Recovery and Institutional Strengthening. Inadequate cost recovery is a major constraint to improved sector performance. Raising the level of cost recovery requires the establishment of effective systems of charging for water and sewerage. Such charges will only be effective if based on the volume of water consumed, with proportional charges for sewerage. Linked to a system of continuous supply at acceptable pressures, it becomes technically possible to organize the charging system on a volumetric basis and while this principle is widely accepted in India these systems of charging do not exist fully in any of the larger Indian towns or cities. A fully metered system of supply would permit greater control over leakage, waste and other forms of unaccounted for water, encourage effective conservation and would reduce operating costs. Financial strengthening is one element of institutional strengthening, and is important for preparation of entities for corporatization. Improved engineering, accounting and management procedures are also required. Again, the proposed project builds on actions already being unidertaken to support these requirements by incorporating progressive metering, a move to full volumetric charging and substantial tariff increases. 1.16 Construction Quality. Througlhout the sector, the quality of construction of new works is extremely poor. Many local authority staff are insufficiently qualified or experienced for the tasks. Relationships between local authority engineers and contractors are invariably strained and the use of qualified consultants is limited. Poorly managed procurement procedures for goods, works and services remain a major problem throughout the sector. Preparation of tender documents and evaluation of tenders are slow. The common practice of fragmentation of works into a large number of contracts is wasteful in administrative time and r esults in difficulties of coordination and management. The proposed project would include major project components and would bring international expertise to the tasks of their design and supervision. 1.17 Links to Environmental Sanitation. The provision of sanitation arrangements must go hand in hand with water supply. Increasing the supply of water will have a consequential impact on the disposal of wastes. In most Indian cities there is a wide gap between the level of water service and the even more serious situation with inadequate sanitation and the outcome has been a segmental approach. As a result, the discharges of waste leads to pollution, health risks and environmental degradation. These problems are exacerbated by poor maintenance of drainage channels where much of the waste is routed. Although the proposed project does not have a sanitation component, this is an important part of MMWSSB's investment program under the existing Bank First Project (see para. 1.20), and under a future project proposal (see para. 2.2).
 - 5 - D. Lessons Learned from the Bank's Involvement in the Sector 1.18 Bank's Prior Experience in India. The Bank Group began supporting urban water supply and sanitation projects in India in 1974 and through to the end of FY1994 had approved twelve projects, which account for US$814 million in IDA Credits and US$173 million in World Bank Loans. Most of the further eleven urban development projects accounting for US$990 million and US$69 million respectively Credits and Loans, have contained substantial components of water supply and sanitation investments. A schedule of these projects is in Annex 9. Of the twelve urban water supply and sanitation projects, five have been single city projects mainly in the metropolitan cities. 1.19 Experience has been that the physical works financed by the Bank Group have been implemented in a satisfactory manner although some implementation delays have been experienced in most cases. Past projects have been less than fully successful in achieving institutional, financial or economic improvements, which have focused on management information systems, accounting and the achievement of full or substantial cost recovery. Failure to implement agreed initiatives within projects has contributed to inefficiencies, inadequate cost recovery and insufficient financing of O&M. The institutional reforms have not always been thoroughly developed or properly presented. Realistic schedules have not always been planned, nor coordinated with the training and other technical assistance needed to facilitate the changes. Nevertheless, there is growing acceptance by the Government of India (GOI) and many state governments of the fundamental objectives incorporated in the Bank's sector program. The main lessons learned are the need for: (a) use of legal covenants where the action is critical to project success; (b) greater flexibility and use of operational action plans to be revised in the light of changing conditions; (c) greater attention to project preparation prior to project effectiveness; (d) persistent supervision; and (e) the active participation by central and state governments and agencies as policy intermediaries for biringing about the necessary reforms in the sector framework. 1.20 Bank's Prior Experience in the Sector in Tamil Nadu and Madras. The Bank is funding one on-going water supply and sanitation project in Madras, (the First Madras Water Supply and Sanitation Project (LN. 2846/CR. 1822-IN) or the First Project) and has funded the recently completed Tamil Nadu Water Supply and Sanitation Project (CR. 1454-IN). CR. 1454-IN in the amount of US$73 million equivalent (Board date of March 1984 and final closing date of December 1994) met its development objectives with substantial compliance of major covenants. There was a need for design changes and project restructuring in 1990 because of prolonged drought which extended the original closing date from June 1990 to December 1994. The First Project in the amount of US$69 million equivalent, for which the Board date was June 1987 with a closing date of December 1995, should meet its development objectives with the exception of a full 35% increase in the supply of water for Madras. Less than full supply arises from delays in the construction of some check dams and lower than expected yields from existing well fields due to the impact of the drought which has affected the region since the early 1980s. Implementation has been satisfactory and legal covenants, including financial performance, are in compliance. E. Bank's Sector Role 1.21 Bank support to the urban water supply sector is dependent on commitments by central and state governments to reform. In the medium term, Bank lending would be in areas where progress has been made in dealing with sector constraints and where there is clear sign of reform effort. The Bank's strategy has been to seek: (al) the efficient utilization of resources through appropriate technology choices and sound engineering design and construction; (b) an improvement in institutional capacity; (c) pricing policies which ericourage conservation of water yet which render services affordable to the

The proposed project would be consistent with all these strategic aims. II. THE PROJECT A. Project Origin and Rationale for Bank Support 2.1 Proposed Sources of Supply. Krishna water will feed into Redhills from late 1995 or early 1996, where a treatment plant is under construction under the First Project, and the water will enter the Madras distribution system directly from the Redhills treatment plant. The current project uses basically the same transmission concept as this earlier scheme and, for this reason, is sometimes referred to as the New Veeranam Project. However, there are important design and implementation management changes to ensure successful completion. 2.4 Rationale and Link to the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS). Following the achievement of many of the objectives of structural reform at the Center, priority of the CAS (draft of March 14, 1995, to be reviewed by Board in June 1995) places priority on implementing state-level sector reforms and improving state finances. These are essential if state governments are to play their key role in the provision of critically needed infrastructure. The lending strategy should reflect the requirements and characteristics of individual states. The proposed project is consistent with this priority. Through increasing the supply of water to the city of Madras, the opportunity for sector reform is increased. The project enhances the drive for financial strengthening of MMWSSB and the program of water conservation. The project improves the framework and environment for private sector-led economic growth by strengthening the public sector's effectiveness in providing an essential service. B. Objectives 2.5 The proposed Second Project would increase the supply of water to Madras and would lead to significant improvements in distribution and conservation with consequential benefits for the population, economy and the environment. The Bank's involvement would be to assist with the financing of the works and development and of providing the stimulus for needed conservation measures and financial discipline. The project would safeguard the interests of persons adversely affected by the project. 2.6 The major project objectives are to: (a) provide water to Madras on an urgent basis; (b) improve the distribution of water within Madras; and (c) strengthen conservation of water through physical means such as leakage detection and repair and the introduction of revised water tariffs and other measures. C. Project Description 2.7 Overview of the Project. The Second Project would exploit part of the yield of an existing agricultural water source, the Veeranam tank, which is a shallow balancing reservoir formed by earth embankments on the Cauvery River system. The Veeranam tank is supplied from the Mettur Reservoir
 - 8 - located on the Tamil Nadu side of the border with Karnataka through a complex series of channels and weirs and from its own and other catchment areas. Infrastructure would be constructed under the project to increase the capacity of the Veeranam tank which, with additional releases from Mettur and a new operating regime at Veeranam, would remove any impact of withdrawing water from the irrigation system which serves local farmers. From the Veeranam tank raw water would be pumped and transported by pipeline to a treatment plant at Vadakkuthu some 20 km away. Thereafter, the treated water would be transported by pipeline to Madras to a terminal reservoir to be provided at Porur, in the south-west of the city. The overall distance from Veeranam to Porur is about 235 km. 192 mid will be withdrawn on a continuous basis from the Veeranam tank, of which 180 mid would reach Madras with about 4% used in operating the treatment plant and 2% losses along the transmission line. From Porur the treated water would be pumped to the city's distribution system. A project component is included to continue the improvement of the distribution system which is underway using Bank assistance under the First Project and also using HUDCO's financing. To the extent financially and technically feasible, distribution system improvements in the proposed project would be targeted at lower income areas of the city. In addition, water conservation improvements would be achieved by MMWSSB through revisions of water tariffs linked to a metering program and physical works which are part of a distribution system strengthening strategy. 2.8 Component 1: Source Works (US$22.1 million; 6.8 percent of base cost). Veeranam tank is an ancient source of irrigation water for the surrounding region. The bund has been formed by a three to four meter earthen embankment nearly 16 km long and a foreshore bund which is 9 km long. Its present 3 2 storage capacity is 27.7 Mm and the water surface area of the tank is 20.8 km . The proposed major engineering works include: raising the Veeranam bund by about 0.6 m by excavating accumulated silt from the floor of the tank, and transporting, placing and consolidating this material to form new embankments or to repair existing embankments; the construction of a parapet wall and other works for prevention of wave erosion; restoration of the existing bunds; construction of a short length of new foreshore bund to prevent submergence of land due to the raising of the reservoir, and the necessary modifications to weirs and the spill-way. Additionally, there will be lining improvements to the principal canal which serves the tank, the Vadavar Channel, and minor irrigation works as part of the effort to safeguard the interests of local farmers. There will be limited displacement of population on the embankments and nearby for which a program of compensation and reinstatement has been agreed (see Annex 6). 2.9 Component 2: Water Transmission, Treatment and Resettlement (US$229.4 million: 70.4 percent). Construction is proposed of: a raw water intake and pumping station; rehabilitation of existing underground storage facilities and construction of an additional storage tank; and, the laying of a transmission main for the raw water from the tank to the treatment plant of 180 mid capacity at Vadakkuthu. The structure for the treatment plant, constructed as part of the 1970s scheme but abandoned, would be renovated and new mechanical and electrical equipment installed. Thereafter there would be the laying of a single transmission main between 1525 and 1875 mm in diameter to convey the water to Porur. The clear water would be pumped from Vadakkuthu to a high level transmission reservoir at Kadam Pulliyar Ridge from where it would flow by gravity. There will be displacement of encroachers on the right of way, and on road margins in Madras. It is supplied primarily by the water released from the Mettur Reservoir located close to the Karnataka/Tamil Nadu State border. The conveyance system to the Veeranam tank consists of a long stretch of the river Colleroon and an unlined water course called the Vadavar Canal, which is 22 km long and terminates at the tank. Attached is a schematic diagram of the Veeranam tank conveyance system. 2. The capacity of the Veeranam tank is 27.74 Mm3 and its water surface area at full tank level is about 20.83 sq. km. In 1923 its capacity was reported to be 40 .80 Mm3 indicating considerable silting since that time. The tank supplies irrigation water to an area of 18, 158 ha in the South Arcot district, but additionally the tank is used to supply irrigation water to a neighboring system, Sethiathope Anicut, at the time of the latter's shortfall. 3. The proposed project would increase the storage of the tank to 41.48 Mm3 by raising the level by 0.61 m. In the context of supplying water to Madras, the Government has stipulated that there should be supplies made available during the irrigation season from July to February by keeping the tank full at the enhanced storage ievel. From February to June there are normally no relk-a-es from Mett!r. The additional capacity at Vecianam tank will ensure the Madras supplies at that time. 4. Analyses have been performed of the potential yield of the tank using historical data. This historical data has utilized daily flows over a 29-year period from 1965-1993. A simulation model has been constructed for assessing the dependability of the tank for irrigation and Madras city water supply under a 100-year scenario. 5. The historic studies indicate there were six drought years over the period 1983-1990, in 1983, 1985, 1987, 1988, 1989 and 1990 of which the last four were consecutively very bad years. It is a bad year when the south west monsoon fails and the Mettur Reservoir is not open for irrigation until the end of July, and a very bad year when along with the failure of the south-west monsoon, the north-east monsoon also fails. 6. An investigation has been made of the capacity of the Mettur Dam, considering the contents of the Dam at the end of February and end of June since 1983, that is, looking at bad and very bad years. It was found that there will always be live storage present in Mettur even after the releases for the special supplementation for Madras and to meet the stipulated irrigation requirements for the farmers served by Veeranam. This was so even in a!l four bad years from 1986 to 1989. 7. An assessment has been made of the geology and seismicity of the zone. This shows clearly that even though the region under consideration is not completely aseismic, there is no seismogenic feature such as a fault line at the location of the tank or nearby. The Veeranam tank has a very wide spread and reservoir induced seismicity is not applicable. 8. The conclusions from the historical studies are as follows:

The environmental assessment (EA) for the project was undertaken by National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (NEERI) under contract to Tamil Nadu Water Supply and Drainage Board (TWAD), beginning in January 1994. The EA report was prepared in accordance with the provisions of World Bank OD 4.01, Environmental Assessment, applicable to Category A projects. 2. In many respects, this project could have been handled as Category B. The transmission main right of way (ROW) had already been acquired, as had the sites that were being considered for the water treatment works. However, the major waterways in MMA are highly polluted due to discharge of wastewater from public and commercial buildings not connected to the sewerage systems and sewage and sullage from the squatter settlements. Cashew plantations are very common in South Arcot district, one of the districts along the ROW. There are nevertheless a few patches of natural forest and reserve forest. doc.repnme: India - Second Madras Water Supply Project
doc.abstracts: Madras has the lowest level of water supply of all metropolitan areas in India and great susceptibility to drought. The project's major objectives are to: 1) provide water from a reliable source within the State to Madras on an urgent basis; 2) improve the distribution of water within Madras; and 3) strengthen conservation. The project will consist of the following: 1) source works at the existing Veeranam irrigation tank to the south of Madras; 2) a transmission pipeline from Veeranam to Madras, a distance of 235 km, with associated treatment and pumping facilities; 3) continuation of distribution improvements within Madras being undertaken in the First Madras Supply Project; 4) a water conservation program including physical works such as leak detection and repairs and tariff increases to encourage more efficient use of water; and 5) technical assistance in the form of project preparation and implementation support. Adequate steps will be taken to ensure people adversely affected benefit from the project where this is possible and otherwise are made no worse off as a result. To remove possible farmer resistance to the proposals at Veeranam, a new regime to regulate the flow has been introduced following consultation under which the irrigation flows will exceed those that would otherwise have occurred.
